How to Cite in MLA 9: Complete MLA 9th Edition Citation Guide

Master MLA 9th edition citation format with comprehensive examples and guidelines for works cited and in-text citations

Introduction

If you are here because MLA citations feel like a moving target, you are not alone. You might have learned MLA 8, built habits that worked, and then opened a new assignment only to hear, ‚ÄúUse MLA 9th edition.‚Äù Now you are stuck wondering what actually changed, what stayed the same, and why your Works Cited page suddenly feels harder to organize. This MLA 9th edition complete guide is designed for that exact moment, when you need clear answers fast, without wading through rules that assume you already know what you are doing.

This MLA citation guide focuses on the practical choices you have to make while writing, revising, and formatting. You will learn how to apply MLA 9 rules consistently across common source types, including books, articles, websites, videos, and databases, even when the information is incomplete or messy. We also address the biggest pain points students report, like MLA 8 vs MLA 9 confusion, complex citation formats that do not look like the examples you were given, and the stress of getting Works Cited organization right when your sources all look different.

You will see, step by step, how MLA formatting decisions connect to readability and alphabetical order. For example, MLA 9 emphasizes author clarity, so you will format names with full first names rather than initials, invert only the first author‚Äôs name, use ‚Äúand‚Äù for two authors, and switch to ‚Äúet al.‚Äù for three or more authors. When there is no author, you will not plug in placeholders like ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù or ‚Äún.d.‚Äù Instead, you will start with the title and still keep your entry easy to alphabetize.

Most importantly, this guide is built to help you troubleshoot real citations, not just copy perfect templates. If your source is missing a date, has a corporate author, or lives inside a larger container like a database or an anthology, you will learn what to prioritize, what to omit, and how to keep your citations consistent from first draft to final submission.

Understanding MLA 9th Edition

Core philosophy of MLA 9

MLA 9 is built around one main idea, consistent, flexible citations that help readers find your sources. Instead of giving you a separate rigid template for every possible source type, MLA asks you to identify the important facts about a source and present them in a standard order. This approach works well because sources keep changing. A poem might appear in a book, then in a database, then on a website. MLA 9 lets you cite all of these using the same logic.

At its core, MLA 9 citations do three jobs:

  1. Give credit to the people whose work you used.
  2. Show what you used, clearly and specifically, so a reader can recognize it.
  3. Help readers locate it, whether it is in print, online, or inside a larger collection.

MLA 9 emphasizes clarity and respect for authorship. That is why author formatting rules matter, including using full first names when available. In a Works Cited list, readers scan quickly, so consistent author formatting and consistent ordering make citations easier to read and easier to alphabetize.

The container system, what it is and why it matters

The MLA ‚Äúcontainer‚Äù system is the method MLA uses to show where a source is located. Many sources are nested inside other sources. For example:

  • A short story is inside an anthology.
  • An academic article is inside a journal, which you might access through a database.
  • A video is on a platform, inside a channel or series.

In MLA terms:

  • The item you are directly using is the source.
  • The larger thing that holds it is the container.

You usually cite the source first, then the container. If there is another larger system that holds the container, you may have a second container.

This matters because readers often need the container to find the source. If you only cite the article title, a reader might not know which journal it came from. If you only cite the journal, a reader might not know which article you used.

What counts as a container

A container is often a publication or platform, such as:

  • A book that contains a chapter, essay, or story
  • A journal that contains an article
  • A website that contains a web page
  • A streaming platform that contains a film or episode
  • A database that contains journal articles or ebooks

The basic MLA 9 Works Cited pattern

MLA 9 uses a standard set of elements, in a typical order. Not every source has every element, and that is fine. Use what is relevant and available.

A common pattern looks like this:

Author. Title of Source. Title of Container, Other contributors, Version, Number, Publisher, Publication date, Location.

If there is a second container, you add it after the first container‚Äôs details:

Author. Title of Source. Title of Container, details. Title of Second Container, details, Location.

Locations can include page ranges for print sources or URLs and DOIs for online sources.

Author rules that support the philosophy

Because MLA citations are meant to be readable and easy to alphabetize, MLA has specific author formatting rules. The following points are especially important for Works Cited entries.

Full first names, not initials (when available)

MLA 9 favors full first names for clarity. This reduces confusion between authors with similar initials and better reflects the author‚Äôs identity.

  • Correct: Morrison, Toni.
  • Incorrect: Morrison, T.

Invert only the first author

The first author is inverted to support alphabetizing in the Works Cited list. Additional authors are not inverted.

  • Correct: Garcia, Maria, and Sanjay Patel.
  • Incorrect: Garcia, Maria and Patel, Sanjay.

Use ‚Äúand‚Äù for two authors

MLA uses the word ‚Äúand,‚Äù not an ampersand, for a formal, consistent style.

  • Correct: Garcia, Maria, and Sanjay Patel.
  • Incorrect: Garcia, Maria, & Sanjay Patel.

Use ‚Äúet al.‚Äù for three or more authors

MLA shortens long author lists to keep citations readable.

  • Correct: Nickels, William, et al.
  • Incorrect: Nickels, William, Smith, John, et al.

No author, start with the title

If no author is listed, MLA does not use placeholders like ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù or ‚Äún.d.‚Äù Instead, begin with the title. Alphabetize by the title, ignoring A, An, and The.

Examples of the container system (with explanations)

Example 1, journal article in a database (two containers)

Scenario: You read an academic article. The article is in a journal, and you accessed it through a database.

Works Cited entry (correct formatting):
Garcia, Maria Elena, and Sanjay Patel. ‚ÄúUrban Heat and Public Health.‚Äù Journal of Environmental Studies, vol. 18, no. 2, 2022, pp. 115-139. JSTOR, https://www.jstor.org/stable/1234567.

How the containers work:
- Source: ‚ÄúUrban Heat and Public Health.‚Äù This is the specific item you used.
- First container: Journal of Environmental Studies. The journal holds the article, so it is the first container.
- Second container: JSTOR. The database holds the journal content in the form you accessed.
- Location: The stable URL helps the reader find it.

Why this matters: If a reader searches the article title, they might find multiple versions. The journal information confirms the exact publication. The database and URL show the access path you used.

Common pitfall: Listing the database but forgetting the journal details. The journal is usually essential because it is the original container.

Example 2, chapter or essay in an edited book (one container)

Scenario: You used one chapter from an anthology edited by someone else.

Works Cited entry (correct formatting):
Morrison, Toni. ‚ÄúMemory and Meaning.‚Äù Contemporary American Essays, edited by John David Smith, Riverbend Press, 2019, pp. 42-58.

How the container works:
- Source: ‚ÄúMemory and Meaning.‚Äù The chapter or essay is the source, so it goes in quotation marks.
- Container: Contemporary American Essays. The book contains the essay, so the book title is the container and is italicized.
- Other contributor: The editor is included because the editor is responsible for the collection.
- Location: Page range shows where the essay appears.

Why this matters: Without the container, a reader cannot locate the essay. Many essays share similar titles, and the book identifies the exact collection.

Common pitfall: Italicizing the essay title instead of the book title. In MLA, the smaller part is usually in quotation marks, and the larger whole is italicized.

Example 3, web page on a website (one container, no author)

Scenario: A web page has no listed author.

Works Cited entry (correct formatting):
‚ÄúClimate Change Effects.‚Äù Nature Today, 14 Mar. 2024, https://www.naturetoday.org/climate-change-effects.

How the container works:
- No author: Start with the page title. Do not write ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù or ‚Äún.d.‚Äù
- Source: ‚ÄúClimate Change Effects.‚Äù This is the specific page.
- Container: Nature Today. The website is the container that hosts the page.
- Location: The URL tells the reader where to find it.

Why this matters: Websites change often. The title, site name, and date help readers confirm they have the right page and understand when it was published.

Common pitfall: Starting with the date or using a placeholder author. MLA wants the title first when there is no author.

Practical tips for using the container system

  • Identify what you actually used. If you watched one episode, cite the episode, not just the series.
  • Think ‚Äúpart‚Äù and ‚Äúwhole.‚Äù The part is the source, the whole is the container.
  • Use the most stable location. Prefer a DOI when available, otherwise use a stable URL.
  • Do not force missing information. MLA does not want invented dates or placeholder authors.
  • Check author names carefully. Use full first names when available, invert only the first author, and use ‚Äúand‚Äù or ‚Äúet al.‚Äù correctly.

Why these rules matter overall

MLA 9‚Äôs philosophy and container system are designed to make citations both consistent and adaptable. The rules are not just formatting habits. They support real reader needs, clear credit, quick scanning in Works Cited, and reliable source retrieval. When you apply the container system carefully and follow MLA author rules, your citations become more trustworthy, and your writing becomes easier for others to verify and build on.

Author Formatting Rules

Overview, why author formatting matters in MLA 9

In MLA 9, author names in the Works Cited entry do more than identify who wrote the source. They also control how your list is alphabetized, how easily readers can find the source, and how consistently your citations communicate credit. When author names are formatted correctly, your Works Cited becomes easy to scan, your sources sort properly by last name, and your citations look professional and reliable.

MLA 9 author formatting is built around a few core ideas:

  • Use full first names whenever possible, not initials.
  • Invert only the first author‚Äôs name, so the entry can be alphabetized by last name.
  • Use the word ‚Äúand‚Äù for two authors, not an ampersand.
  • For three or more authors, list only the first author followed by ‚Äúet al.‚Äù
  • If there is no author, start with the title instead of inserting placeholders like ‚ÄúAnonymous.‚Äù

The sections below focus on full names, name inversion, two authors with ‚Äúand,‚Äù and ‚Äúet al.‚Äù for three or more authors.

Use full first names, not initials

The rule

MLA 9 emphasizes full first names rather than initials. This supports clarity and respects the author‚Äôs identity. When you have access to the full name, you should write it out.

Correct and incorrect patterns

  • Correct: Morrison, Toni
  • Incorrect: Morrison, T. (initial used instead of the full first name)
  • Incorrect: Morrison, T. E. (initials used for first and middle names)

Practical tip

If a database record shows initials but the full name appears elsewhere in the source, use the full name from the source itself. If you truly cannot find the full first name, MLA allows you to cite what is provided, but your goal should be to use the fullest form available.

Common pitfalls

  • Replacing first names with initials because it ‚Äúlooks academic.‚Äù In MLA 9, that is usually a mistake.
  • Abbreviating middle names automatically. Middle names are optional, but if you include them, do not turn them into initials if the full middle name is available.

Invert the first author‚Äôs name (Last, First Middle)

The rule

The first author in a Works Cited entry is inverted. Write the last name first, then a comma, then the first name and any middle name.

This is the standard opening format for MLA citations because it supports alphabetical ordering by last name.

Correct and incorrect patterns

  • Correct: Smith, John David
  • Incorrect: John David Smith (not inverted)

Practical tip

Think of inversion as a filing system. Libraries and Works Cited pages need a consistent ‚Äúfile under last name‚Äù format. Inversion makes ‚ÄúSmith‚Äù the first thing a reader sees, so they can locate the entry quickly.

Common pitfalls

  • Inverting every author in the list. In MLA, only the first author is inverted.
  • Forgetting the comma after the last name. The comma is part of the standard format.

Two authors, use ‚Äúand,‚Äù do not invert the second author

The rule

For a source with two authors, list the first author inverted, then add a comma, then the word and, then the second author in normal order.

Correct and incorrect patterns

  • Correct: Garcia, Maria, and Sanjay Patel
  • Incorrect: Garcia, Maria, & Sanjay Patel (uses an ampersand)
  • Incorrect: Garcia, Maria and Patel, Sanjay (second author incorrectly inverted)
  • Incorrect: Garcia, Maria, Patel, Sanjay (missing ‚Äúand‚Äù)

Why MLA does this

MLA keeps the first author inverted to preserve alphabetical order in the Works Cited. The second author stays in normal order because the entry is already alphabetized by the first author‚Äôs last name. This approach also reads more naturally.

Practical tips

  • Always spell out and. Do not use ‚Äú&‚Äù even if the source uses it.
  • Keep the punctuation consistent. The comma before ‚Äúand‚Äù is part of the MLA pattern shown in standard models.

Common pitfalls

  • Treating MLA like APA and using an ampersand.
  • Inverting both names, which can confuse readers and disrupt consistency across entries.

Three or more authors, use ‚Äúet al.‚Äù after the first author only

The rule

For a source with three or more authors, list only the first author, in inverted form, followed by a comma and et al. Do not list the second or third author before ‚Äúet al.‚Äù

Correct and incorrect patterns

  • Correct: Nickels, William, et al.
  • Incorrect: Nickels, William, Smith, John, et al. (lists extra authors before et al.)
  • Incorrect: Nickels, W., et al. (uses an initial)

Why MLA does this

Long author lists can make Works Cited entries bulky and harder to scan. Using ‚Äúet al.‚Äù keeps the citation readable while still crediting the first listed author and indicating that additional authors exist.

Practical tips

  • Include the period after al. because it is an abbreviation.
  • Keep the comma before et al. as shown in MLA models.
  • Do not italicize ‚Äúet al.‚Äù in MLA Works Cited entries.

Common pitfalls

  • Listing multiple authors and then adding ‚Äúet al.‚Äù anyway. MLA wants the first author only, then ‚Äúet al.‚Äù
  • Forgetting the comma before ‚Äúet al.‚Äù
  • Using initials for the first author when the full first name is available.

Examples with detailed explanations (correct MLA 9 formatting)

Example 1, one author with full first name and inversion

Correct author element:
Morrison, Toni

Why it is correct:
- The name is inverted, last name first, then a comma, then the full first name.
- It avoids initials, which MLA 9 discourages when the full name is known.
- This format ensures the entry will be alphabetized under ‚ÄúMorrison‚Äù in the Works Cited list.

Common mistake to avoid:
Writing Morrison, T. may seem shorter, but it reduces clarity and does not follow the MLA 9 preference for full first names.

Example 2, two authors with ‚Äúand,‚Äù second author not inverted

Correct author element:
Garcia, Maria, and Sanjay Patel

Why it is correct:
- The first author is inverted to support alphabetizing by last name.
- The second author is in normal order because the entry is already filed under Garcia.
- ‚ÄúAnd‚Äù is spelled out, which is MLA style.

Common mistakes to avoid:
- Garcia, Maria, & Sanjay Patel is incorrect because MLA uses ‚Äúand,‚Äù not ‚Äú&.‚Äù
- Garcia, Maria and Patel, Sanjay is incorrect because the second author should not be inverted.

Example 3, three or more authors using ‚Äúet al.‚Äù

Correct author element:
Nickels, William, et al.

Why it is correct:
- The first author is inverted and uses the full first name.
- ‚ÄúEt al.‚Äù signals additional authors without listing them.
- The comma before ‚Äúet al.‚Äù matches MLA formatting expectations.

Common mistake to avoid:
Nickels, William, Smith, John, et al. is incorrect because MLA does not want extra names before ‚Äúet al.‚Äù in the Works Cited author field.

Quick checklist, author formatting in MLA 9

Do

  • Use the author‚Äôs full first name when available.
  • Invert the first author‚Äôs name, Last, First Middle.
  • For two authors, use ‚Äúand,‚Äù keep the second author in normal order.
  • For three or more authors, use the first author only plus ‚Äúet al.‚Äù

Avoid

  • Initials when the full first name is known.
  • Inverting the second author in a two author entry.
  • Using an ampersand.
  • Listing multiple authors and then adding ‚Äúet al.‚Äù anyway.

If you want, I can also add a short section showing how these author rules connect to in text citations, especially how ‚Äúet al.‚Äù appears in parenthetical citations.

Title and Source Formatting

Overview, MLA 9 Title Formatting Basics

In MLA 9, titles do more than identify a source. They also tell your reader what kind of source it is and how it relates to other sources. MLA uses three main title formatting rules:

  1. All titles use Title Case capitalization, no matter the source type.
  2. Complete, standalone works are italicized.
  3. Shorter works that appear inside a larger work use quotation marks.

These rules come from the MLA Handbook, 9th edition, Section 2.5, and they apply across your Works Cited entries and, in most cases, in your prose when you mention titles in the body of your paper.

Title Case in MLA 9, What to Capitalize

The core rule, Use Title Case for all titles

MLA requires Title Case for every title you write in a citation, including books, articles, web pages, films, podcasts, and more. Title Case means you capitalize:

  • The first word of the title
  • The last word of the title
  • All principal words, such as nouns, pronouns, verbs, adjectives, and adverbs

You generally lowercase the following words unless they are the first or last word:

  • Articles: a, an, the
  • Coordinating conjunctions: and, but, or, nor, for, so, yet
  • Prepositions: in, on, of, to, at, by, for, and similar short connecting words

Why Title Case matters

Title Case creates consistency across citations. Readers can scan a Works Cited page quickly when titles follow the same capitalization pattern. It also helps avoid confusion when a title includes a mix of proper nouns, subtitles, and quoted titles.

Common Title Case pitfalls to avoid

  • Using sentence case (only capitalizing the first word and proper nouns).
    Incorrect: "The impact of climate change"
    Correct: "The Impact of Climate Change"

  • Capitalizing every word, including articles and short prepositions.
    Incorrect: "The Impact Of Climate Change"
    Correct: "The Impact of Climate Change"

  • Forgetting to capitalize the last word if it is a preposition.
    Example: You still capitalize the last word even if it is ‚Äúof‚Äù or ‚Äúto.‚Äù
    Correct: "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love"
    Correct: "A Guide to"

Italics, When the Work Is Complete and Standalone

What italics signal in MLA 9

Use italics for a title when the source is a complete work. In MLA terms, these works are often containers, meaning they can hold smaller works inside them.

Italicize titles such as:

  • Books
  • Journal names
  • Website names
  • Films
  • Television series

These are works that can usually stand on their own. If you can imagine holding it as a whole item, or visiting it as a whole site or publication, it is often italicized.

Why italics matter

Italics help readers recognize the ‚Äúbig‚Äù source at a glance. This is especially important in MLA citations because the container system depends on clear signals. If you italicize a journal name, your reader immediately understands that an article title will likely appear inside it.

Common italics mistakes

  • Using quotation marks for a book, film, or website name.
    Incorrect: "Beloved"
    Correct: Beloved

  • Forgetting to italicize the container title in a Works Cited entry.
    If you cite an article, the journal name should be italicized.

Quotation Marks, When the Work Is Shorter and Part of a Larger Whole

What quotation marks signal in MLA 9

Use quotation marks for a title when the source is a shorter work that appears inside a larger container. These are not usually published as independent, self-contained works.

Use quotation marks for titles such as:

  • Articles (magazine, journal, newspaper)
  • Chapters in a book
  • Web pages (a page on a larger website)
  • Poems
  • Short stories
  • Television episodes

Quotation marks tell the reader, ‚ÄúThis title belongs to something bigger.‚Äù

Why quotation marks matter

Quotation marks prevent confusion about what you are citing. For example, if you italicize an article title by mistake, a reader might think it is a journal name or a standalone publication. Quotation marks keep the hierarchy clear, which helps your citations communicate structure.

Common quotation mark mistakes

  • Italicizing an article title instead of using quotation marks.
    Incorrect: Modern Storytelling
    Correct: "Modern Storytelling"

  • Leaving off quotation marks entirely.
    Incorrect: Modern Storytelling
    Correct: "Modern Storytelling"

Never Use Both Italics and Quotation Marks on the Same Title

MLA 9 does not allow double formatting for the same title. Do not combine italics and quotation marks, even if you want extra emphasis. Choose one formatting style based on whether the work is complete (italics) or shorter (quotation marks).

Incorrect examples:
- "Book Title"
- "Article Title"

Correct approach:
- Book Title
- "Article Title"

This rule matters because double formatting makes the citation harder to read and breaks MLA consistency. It can also confuse the reader about whether the work is a container or an item inside a container.

Examples, Correct MLA 9 Title Formatting With Explanations

Example 1, Journal article inside a journal (quotation marks plus italics)

Correct formatting (titles only):
"Talk to Me: Engaging Reluctant Writers." Journal of Modern Arts.

Why this is correct:
- The article title, "Talk to Me: Engaging Reluctant Writers", is a shorter work published inside a larger source, so it uses quotation marks.
- The journal title, Journal of Modern Arts, is the container, so it is italicized.
- Both titles are in Title Case, including the subtitle after the colon.

Tip: If you see a citation structure where one title comes first and another title follows it, the first is often the shorter work in quotation marks, and the second is often the container in italics.

Example 2, Chapter in a book (chapter in quotes, book in italics)

Correct formatting (titles only):
"Modern Storytelling." Beloved: A Novel of Love.

Why this is correct:
- A chapter is part of a book, so the chapter title uses quotation marks.
- The book is a complete work, so the book title is italicized.
- The book title remains in Title Case, and the subtitle after the colon is also in Title Case.

Common pitfall: Students sometimes italicize the chapter title because it ‚Äúfeels important.‚Äù In MLA, importance does not control formatting. The work‚Äôs relationship to a larger container does.

Example 3, Web page on a website (page in quotes, website in italics)

Correct formatting (titles only):
"The Impact of Climate Change." National Geographic.

Why this is correct:
- A specific web page is usually part of a larger website, so the page title uses quotation marks.
- The website name is the container, so it is italicized.
- The title uses Title Case. The word ‚Äúof‚Äù stays lowercase because it is a preposition and it is not the first or last word.

Practical tip: If you are citing a page you can navigate to from a site‚Äôs menu, it is often a shorter work. The site name is usually the container.

Practical Tips for Getting Titles Right in MLA 9

Tip 1, Ask one question to choose italics or quotation marks

Ask: Is this a complete work, or is it part of something bigger?
- Complete, standalone work, use italics.
- Part of a larger container, use "quotation marks".

Tip 2, Watch for containers in Works Cited entries

If your source has a clear container, such as a journal, edited book, or website, the smaller part is usually in quotation marks, and the container is italicized.

Tip 3, Keep Title Case consistent, especially with subtitles

If a title includes a colon, capitalize the first word after the colon.
Correct: "Talk to Me: Engaging Reluctant Writers"
Incorrect: "Talk to Me: engaging reluctant writers"

Tip 4, Do not ‚Äústylize‚Äù titles for emphasis

MLA formatting is not about emphasis. It is about clarity and structure. Avoid adding bold, underlining, or double formatting.

Why These Rules Matter in an MLA 9 Citation Guide

Title formatting is one of the fastest ways instructors and readers check MLA accuracy. Correct Title Case and correct use of italics or quotation marks show that you understand how sources are organized. They also make your citations easier to read, which supports MLA‚Äôs main goal, helping readers locate your sources quickly and reliably.

If you want, I can also provide a quick checklist you can paste into your citation guide, or I can format a full Works Cited entry example for each of the three cases above.

Dates, Publishers, and Locations

Overview, why MLA date rules matter

In MLA 9, dates are not decorative details. They help readers confirm when a source was published, distinguish between versions, and locate the exact item you used. Consistent date formatting also signals that your Works Cited entries follow MLA‚Äôs standard ‚Äúpublication sequence,‚Äù which is the order in which core elements appear.

MLA date rules matter most when:

  • A source exists in multiple versions or updates over time, such as online articles, reports, and databases.
  • You need to show the timeliness of evidence, such as news reporting or scientific findings.
  • A reader needs to find the same source quickly, using your citation as a roadmap.

The key MLA 9 ideas to remember are:

  • Put the date in the correct position in the citation, usually after the publisher.
  • Use Day Month Year for specific dates, with abbreviated months and no commas.
  • Use only the year when that is all the source provides, such as many books.
  • Do not invent a date or use placeholders like ‚Äún.d.‚Äù
  • Present URLs cleanly, usually without http:// or https://.
  • Present DOIs in a consistent, usable format.

Date placement in MLA 9, after the publisher

The rule

In MLA 9, the publication date follows the publisher in the publication sequence, and it comes before page numbers or a URL. This is a frequent point of confusion because other styles, such as APA, often place the date near the author.

Use this sequence:

Publisher, Date, Page numbers or URL.

This matches the MLA principle that you move from who produced the source (publisher) to when it appeared (date) to where it is located (pages or link).

Correct and incorrect order

  • Correct: Publisher, 2024, pp. 45-58.
  • Incorrect: Publisher. pp. 45-58, 2024.
    This is incorrect because the date is placed after the page range.
  • Incorrect: Author. (2024). Title.
    This is incorrect because MLA does not place the date in parentheses after the author.

Practical tip

When you build a Works Cited entry, locate the publisher first, then ask, ‚ÄúWhat date does the source provide,‚Äù then add pages or the URL. If you already typed the URL and then notice the date, you probably need to move the date earlier in the entry.

Day Month Year format for specific dates

When to use it

Use Day Month Year for sources that provide a specific publication date, especially:

  • Journal, magazine, and newspaper articles
  • Webpages and online news stories
  • Posts or entries that show an exact date

The format

MLA 9 uses:

Day Month Year

  • No commas in the date.
  • Months are abbreviated in standard MLA form: Jan., Feb., Mar., Apr., May, June, July, Aug., Sept., Oct., Nov., Dec.
  • The day is written as a number, not ‚Äú05,‚Äù and not spelled out.

Examples of correct dates:

  • 5 Feb. 2024
  • 28 Dec. 2025

Common incorrect formats:

  • Feb. 5, 2024
    Incorrect because it uses month day year and includes a comma.
  • 2024-02-05
    Incorrect because it uses ISO format.

Practical tip

If you are copying a date from a website, it often appears in American style, like ‚ÄúFebruary 5, 2024.‚Äù Convert it to MLA style by moving the day first, abbreviating the month, and removing the comma: 5 Feb. 2024.

Year-only dates for books and similar sources

When to use year only

Many sources, especially books and films, often provide only a year. In that case, MLA uses just the year, with no parentheses.

Correct:

  • 2024.

Incorrect:

  • (2024)
    Incorrect because MLA does not use parentheses around the year in Works Cited entries.

Practical tip

If a title page lists only a year, do not try to add a month or day from another place unless the source itself clearly provides it as the publication date. MLA prefers what the source presents as its publication information.

No date available, omit the date element

The rule

If no publication date is available, MLA 9 says to omit the date entirely. Do not use ‚Äún.d.‚Äù and do not write ‚Äúno date.‚Äù

Correct approach:

  • Author. Title. Publisher, URL.

Incorrect approach:

  • Publisher, n.d., URL.

Practical tip

Before deciding there is no date, check common locations:

  • The top or bottom of a webpage, near the headline or byline
  • The site footer, which sometimes shows ‚Äúlast updated‚Äù
  • The PDF cover page or first page for reports
  • Database record details for articles

If you still cannot find a publication date, omit it and consider including an access date, especially if the content might change.

Access dates, when and how to include them

When access dates help

Access dates are optional in MLA, but they are recommended for online content that changes frequently, such as:

  • Wikis
  • Dynamic databases
  • News pages that may be updated
  • Pages without a clear publication date

How to format access dates

Place the access date at the end of the entry, after the URL, using:

Accessed Day Month Year.

Examples:

  • Accessed 28 Dec. 2025.
  • URL. Accessed 5 Feb. 2024.

Common mistakes:

  • Leaving out the word ‚ÄúAccessed‚Äù
  • Using the wrong date format, such as ‚ÄúFeb. 5, 2024‚Äù
  • Placing the access date before the URL

Practical tip

If your instructor or institution has a preference, follow it. If not, a good habit is to include access dates when you cite web content that might look different next week than it does today.

URLs in MLA 9, omit http:// and https://

The rule and the purpose

MLA generally recommends using URLs without the protocol, meaning you usually remove http:// and https://. This keeps citations clean and readable while still giving enough information for a reader to locate the source.

Example:

  • Use: www.example.com/article
  • Not: https://www.example.com/article

Practical tip

Copy the full URL, then delete the protocol. Keep the rest exactly as it appears, including any stable identifiers. If a URL is extremely long and clearly session-based, look for a ‚Äúpermalink,‚Äù ‚Äústable URL,‚Äù or ‚Äúshare‚Äù link provided by the site or database.

DOI formatting in MLA 9

What a DOI is

A DOI, or Digital Object Identifier, is a stable link to an academic article or other digital publication. Unlike many URLs, a DOI is designed to remain consistent over time.

How to format it

In MLA 9, present the DOI as a DOI link when possible, commonly in this form:

  • doi.org/10.xxxx/xxxxx

This fits MLA‚Äôs preference for streamlined links, similar to removing https:// from URLs.

Practical tip

If your database provides both a URL and a DOI, prefer the DOI because it is more stable. Treat the DOI like the location element, and place it at the end of the entry where the URL would go.

Examples with correct formatting and explanations

Example 1, online news article with a specific date and a URL

Correct MLA 9 format (model):
Last Name, First Name. ‚ÄúTitle of Article.‚Äù Website Name, Publisher, 5 Feb. 2024, www.example.com/news/story.

Why this is correct
- The date uses Day Month Year and has no comma.
- The date appears after the publisher and before the URL.
- The URL is presented without https://.

Common pitfall to avoid
- Do not write: Feb. 5, 2024 and do not place the date after the URL.

Example 2, journal article with page numbers and a DOI

Correct MLA 9 format (model):
Last Name, First Name. ‚ÄúTitle of Article.‚Äù Journal Title, vol. 12, no. 3, Publisher, 2024, pp. 45-58, doi.org/10.1234/abcd.5678.

Why this is correct
- The year appears after the publisher, before the page range and DOI.
- The order is correct: Publisher, Date, Pages, DOI.
- The DOI is formatted as a clean, usable link.

Common pitfall to avoid
- Do not place the date after the pages. That breaks MLA‚Äôs publication sequence.

Example 3, webpage with no publication date, include an access date

Correct MLA 9 format (model):
Last Name, First Name. ‚ÄúTitle of Page.‚Äù Website Name, Publisher, www.example.com/topic/page. Accessed 28 Dec. 2025.

Why this is correct
- The citation omits the publication date entirely because none is available.
- It does not use ‚Äún.d.‚Äù
- The access date is placed at the end and uses Day Month Year format.

Common pitfall to avoid
- Do not insert a placeholder like n.d. or no date. MLA prefers omission.

Quick checklist, date and link accuracy

  • Put the date after the publisher and before page numbers or a URL.
  • Use Day Month Year for specific dates, abbreviate the month, and use no commas.
  • Use year only when that is all the source provides, with no parentheses.
  • If there is no date, omit the date element, do not use ‚Äún.d.‚Äù
  • Add ‚ÄúAccessed Day Month Year‚Äù at the end when content changes or no date is given.
  • Remove http:// and https:// from URLs in most cases.
  • Prefer DOIs when available, format them as doi.org/... and place them in the location position at the end.

In-Text Citations

What MLA 9 in-text citations do

MLA 9 in-text citations tell readers two things quickly.

  1. Who the information came from.
  2. Where to find it in the source.

They work with your Works Cited list. The in-text citation points to the first element of the matching Works Cited entry, usually the author‚Äôs last name, and it often includes a page number so the reader can locate the exact passage.

In MLA, in-text citations are usually brief because the goal is to keep the focus on your writing while still giving clear credit.

Two main styles, parenthetical and narrative

MLA 9 allows two common ways to place in-text citations.

Parenthetical citations

A parenthetical citation goes in parentheses, usually at the end of the sentence that uses the source. It typically includes the author‚Äôs last name and a page number.

Format:
(Author Page)

Key punctuation rule: No comma between author and page number, and no p. or pp. in the parentheses.

Correct: (Morrison 42)
Incorrect: (Morrison, 42)
Incorrect: (Morrison, p. 42)

This follows MLA 9 guidance that in-text citations use the author and page number only, without p. or pp. and without a comma.

Narrative citations

A narrative citation builds the author‚Äôs name into your sentence. Then you put only the page number in parentheses.

Format:
Author states ... (Page).

Example: Morrison suggests that memory shapes identity (42).

Narrative citations can read more smoothly because the author‚Äôs name becomes part of your prose. They also reduce repetition if you are discussing the same author over several sentences.

The core rule, author-page format, without p. or pp.

MLA‚Äôs default in-text citation format is often called author-page. It looks like this:

  • Parenthetical: (LastName 123)
  • Narrative: LastName argues ... (123).

What not to include

MLA in-text citations do not use these items in the parentheses:

  • No p. or pp.
  • No comma between author and page number
  • No publication year
  • No publisher name

This simplicity matters because MLA is designed to keep citations short and consistent. Readers can scan quickly, then use the Works Cited entry for full details.

Why MLA avoids p. and pp. in parentheses

MLA assumes that a number after the author refers to a page number when the source has pages. Adding p. or pp. is unnecessary in MLA‚Äôs system and makes citations longer and less consistent. MLA does use p. and pp. in Works Cited entries for print page ranges, but that is a different part of the documentation system.

Where the citation goes in the sentence

In most cases, place the in-text citation at the end of the sentence, before the final period.

Example:
The narrator connects personal history to collective trauma (Morrison 42).

If you cite a source in the middle of a sentence, the citation goes right after the quoted or paraphrased material, and you continue your sentence after it.

Example:
The novel frames memory as ‚Äúa place you can revisit‚Äù (Morrison 42), which complicates the idea of a stable identity.

Practical tip: If you are unsure, default to placing the parenthetical citation at the end of the sentence that contains the borrowed idea.

Handling sources without page numbers

Many online sources do not have stable page numbers. MLA still expects you to help the reader locate the information, but you should not invent page numbers.

If the source has no page numbers, omit the page number

For many web pages, you will cite only the author or title element used in your Works Cited entry.

Example: (Nguyen)
If there is no author and you use the title in Works Cited, shorten the title in the in-text citation. Put the shortened title in quotation marks if the source is an article or web page.

Example: ("Urban Gardens")

If the source has other location markers, use them when helpful

MLA allows you to use other clear markers when page numbers are missing, as long as they help your reader find the passage. Common options include:

  • Chapter numbers in ebooks that label chapters clearly
  • Section headings on a web page, especially if the page is long
  • Paragraph numbers, but only if they are already provided in the source

If you use a heading, keep it short and readable.

Example: (Nguyen, "Community Partnerships")

Practical tip: Do not add paragraph numbers unless the site or document already numbers them. If you must guide readers to a location, a section heading is often more natural than counting paragraphs yourself.

Examples with correct formatting and detailed explanations

Example 1, parenthetical citation with a page number

Sentence with paraphrase:
Sethe‚Äôs memories repeatedly interrupt the present, showing how the past remains active rather than finished (Morrison 42).

Why this is correct:
- The citation uses author-page format: last name plus page number.
- There is no comma between the author and page number.
- There is no p. or pp. in the in-text citation.
- The citation appears before the final period, which is standard MLA placement.

Common pitfall to avoid:
Do not write (Morrison, p. 42). MLA in-text citations do not use p. and do not use a comma.

Example 2, narrative citation with a page number

Sentence with quotation:
Morrison describes rememory as something that can be encountered again, not simply recalled, which makes the past feel physically present (42).

Why this is correct:
- The author‚Äôs name appears in the sentence, so the parentheses contain only the page number.
- The page number is still necessary because it helps readers locate the exact quoted wording.
- The citation stays brief, which is one of MLA‚Äôs main goals.

Practical tip:
Use narrative citations when you are analyzing an author‚Äôs ideas across multiple sentences. It can reduce repetition and make your paragraph flow better.

Example 3, source without page numbers (web page)

Imagine you are citing a web article that has an author but no page numbers.

Sentence with paraphrase:
Nguyen explains that long-term garden projects succeed when organizers build partnerships with local schools and libraries (Nguyen).

Why this is correct:
- The source has no page numbers, so the citation includes only the author name.
- The author name points clearly to the matching Works Cited entry that begins with Nguyen.
- You did not insert a page number or use p. or pp..

Common pitfall to avoid:
Do not use a URL in the in-text citation. In MLA, URLs belong in the Works Cited entry, not in the parentheses.

Why these MLA 9 rules matter

They help readers verify your evidence quickly

A consistent author-page system lets your reader find the exact place you used. That matters for credibility, especially when you quote or make a detailed claim based on a specific passage.

They prevent accidental plagiarism

Even when you paraphrase, you still need an in-text citation. MLA‚Äôs short format makes it easy to cite frequently, which is the safest habit.

They keep your writing readable

MLA in-text citations are designed to be compact. Avoiding extra labels like p. and pp. helps your sentences look cleaner and reduces distraction.

Practical tips and common pitfalls

Tips

  • Cite at the end of the sentence unless there is a clear reason to cite earlier.
  • Use narrative citations when you want to emphasize the author in your discussion.
  • If there is no page number, cite the author or shortened title, and consider adding a section heading for long web pages.
  • Keep your in-text citation consistent with your Works Cited entry‚Äôs first element.

Common pitfalls

  • Adding p. or pp. in parentheses, MLA does not use them in in-text citations.
  • Putting a comma between author and page number, MLA uses a space only.
  • Forgetting to cite paraphrases, not just direct quotes.
  • Using page numbers that do not exist for a web page, omit them instead.

If you share the types of sources you are using, such as books, journal articles, database PDFs, or web pages, I can provide model in-text citations for each and show how they match Works Cited entries in MLA 9.

üîç Test What You've Learned

Try checking one of your own MLA citations

‚ùå Common Errors to Avoid

‚úÖ Validation Checklist

Use this checklist to verify your citations before submission:

  • Author names MUST use full first names, not initials. In MLA 9, the emphasis is on full names to provide clarity and respect for the author's identity. The first author's name is inverted (Last, First Middle), while subsequent authors in two-author works use normal order (First Last).
  • First author name MUST be inverted (Last, First Middle). This applies to all source types and is the standard opening format for MLA citations. The inversion facilitates alphabetical ordering in the Works Cited list.
  • For TWO authors: use 'and' between names (second name NOT inverted). The word 'and' is preferred in MLA for its formality and readability.
  • For THREE OR MORE authors: use 'et al.' after first author only. Do not list additional authors before 'et al.' This simplifies lengthy author lists while maintaining proper attribution. The first author must still use full first name, not initials.
  • NO AUTHOR: Start with title (ignore 'A', 'An', 'The' for alphabetization). Do not use 'n.d.' or 'Anonymous'. The title becomes the first element and should maintain proper formatting (quotes for short works, italics for complete works).
  • ALL titles MUST use Title Case (capitalize all major words). This includes articles, books, websites, and all other sources. Title Case means capitalizing the first and last words, and all principal words (nouns, pronouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs). Articles (a, an, the), coordinating conjunctions, and prepositions are lowercase unless first or last word.
  • Shorter works use QUOTATION MARKS: Article titles, chapter titles, web page titles, poems, short stories, episodes. These are works that are part of a larger container. Quotation marks indicate the work is not standalone.
  • Complete works use ITALICS: Book titles, journal names, website names, films, TV series. These are standalone, self-contained works that serve as containers for shorter works. Italics indicate independence and completeness.
  • Do NOT use both italics AND quotation marks on same title. This is redundant and incorrect. Choose one based on whether the work is shorter (quotes) or complete (italics).
  • Date placement: AFTER publisher, BEFORE page numbers/URL. The date follows the publisher in the publication sequence.
